data.text: Contents
Introduction

Cancer constitutional standards were introduced in 2009 to ensure that patients received timely diagnosis and treatment with the aim of improving cancer survival and ensuring as good a patient experience as possible.

Cancer constitutional standards require that, with a small number of exceptions, patients referred to hospital on an urgent cancer pathway by their general practitioner, or whose pathway is ‘upgraded' to this by a secondary care clinician, should receive their first cancer treatment within 62 days of the referral being received.
These standards also require that patients should receive first treatment within 31 days of the decision to treat being made.

Exceptions to this are for children's cancer, testicular cancer and acute leukaemia where first treatment should be within 31 days of referral, reflecting the more urgent need for treatment in these conditions.
For patients whose treatment is delayed beyond the times set by the constitutional standards, it is important to understand whether or not they may have come to harm as a result of the delay
This is usually done by assessing whether potential harm has been caused after first treatment has been delivered

However, a more pro-active approach, with the intention of mitigating any possible harm caused by delay, would be to implement a review by the clinical team of any patient waiting beyond a defined time on the diagnostic and treatment pathway to ensure that they are not coming to excess harm as a result of the long wait. Work by East of England Cancer Alliance has suggested this point should be day  on the pathway.

Not all patients whose diagnosis and/ or treatment is delayed beyond that which is clinically desirable will breach constitutional standards or be waiting a long time on a cancer pathway. This may occur particularly during a pandemic when waits for access to routine care may be long. The suspicion of cancer may only be become apparent at first routine out-patient appointment and therefore, although diagnostics and treatment from the point of ‘consultant upgrade' may meet constitution standards, the patient has waited a significant time for these from first, routine referral.
Clinical harm can be defined as unintended injury resulting from or contributed to by medical care that requires additional monitoring, treatment or hospitalisation or that results in death
Possible harm as a result of delayed cancer diagnosis may be physical or psychological

While possible physical harm is difficult to define, it is generally accepted, nationally, as being indicated where a patient has undergone more, or different treatment, as a result of the delay, or where the patient has suffered more problems because of the delay than would otherwise be expected as a result of the disease.

Waiting for a cancer diagnosis and/ or treatment is often an anxious time for patients and families and any delay may result in excess psychological harm. Psychological harm is a type of damage to the mind that occurs as a result of a severely distressing event. Harm could be the result of an overwhelming amount of stress that exceeds one's ability to cope,

or  integrate  the  emotions  involved  with  that  experience.  Defining  psychological  harm caused by the delay, over and above that caused by a cancer diagnosis and treatment is difficult, but generally accepted to be mitigated by support from the clinical team, often the clinical nurse specialist. No harm is therefore usually accepted as being the absence of any clear evidence of harm from the delay (PALS concerns, complaints) along with evidence of support from the clinical team
Scope
The purpose of this document is to outline the approach to assessing for, and mitigating against, possible harm in patients who have a delay in cancer diagnosis and treatment when:
The patient has been diagnosed with and treated for cancer but there has been a delay causing a breach of the 62 or  day constitutional standard
The patient is being managed on a cancer pathway and there is likely to be a significant delay to diagnosis and/ or treatment
The patient has not been referred on an urgent cancer referral pathway and has waited a significant time before  subsequent diagnosis and management on an urgent cancer pathway
Definitions

table_items.text: GP/GDP/Optometrist referral for suspected cancer requiring appointment within 14 days.
Cancer Waiting Times measure the NHS' performance against the national NHS Constitution Standards to monitor the timely delivery of services to patients.

Hospital specialists have the right to ensure that patients who are not referred urgently as suspected cancer referrals or through the screening programmes, but who have symptoms or signs indicating a high suspicion of cancer, are managed on the 62 day pathway. This can be achieved by upgrading the patients onto a 62 day upgrade pathway.
A clinical decision is taken to treat the patient.

Clinically led group that determines the level of investigation required for incidents that have occurred. This group also signs off root cause analysis investigations and action plans as a result of serious incidents, never events and internal investigations.

An intervention intended to manage a patient's condition, disease or injury and avoid further intervention. What constitutes First Definitive Treatment is a matter for clinical judgment, in consultation with others as appropriate, including the patient.
Clinically led panel to review/validate/action completed harm reviews and develop lessons learnt or actions for system where applicable

An MDT comprises of medical and non-medical professionals who are responsible for the cancer patient's care. It includes clinicians from a variety of disciplines, the exact constituent are described for each tumour site as part of Quality Surveillance requirements.

A report used to ensure the maximum waiting time targets are achieved by identifying the patient wait time along that pathways and patients who are at risk of being treated outside the pathway requirements

Root cause analysis (RCA) was developed for the health services to promote a systematic approach to the investigation of serious incidents. A good RCA investigation will identify any underlying system and process issues that may have caused or contributed to the incident.
An incident that occurred in relation to NHS-funded services and care resulting in unexpected or avoidable death, harm or injury to patient, carer, staff or visitor.
A referral received following an investigation as part of a screening programme (Breast, Bowel or Cervical).

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Cancer Committee:
Ensure that the number of 62+ day breaches by tumour site is a standing agenda item. The data will include completion performance for hospital and breakdown by tumour site
Receive and monitor the tumour site exception reports as a standing agenda item, ensuring action is taken to mitigate avoidable delays
Receive a paper incorporating the outcome and themes from LHRPs which will be presented to the Quality Governance Committee
Escalate and share, as appropriate, any themes/learning with the Quality Improvement Board (formally CQRG) and the MSE Health and Care Partnership Cancer, Palliative and End of Life Care Board
Review all cases where a Serious Incident (SI) is declared.
Directorate / Divisional Governance Groups:
Maintain oversight of all Harm Reviews relevant to their directorate, oversee and collate reports for all Serious Incidents
Ensure that the reviews are completed and any actions/learning are shared
Ensure themes and trends are incorporated into the individual action plans
Chief Executive:

Has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has robust process in place for harm reviews, oversight of completion, ensuring lessons learnt and actions identified are taken within the organisation. Ensures that there is a process in place to pro-actively manage and mitigate possible harm, both physical and psychological, in patients who are waiting over  days for cancer treatment
Managing Director:

As the site's accountable officer is responsible for ensuring the hospital has robust, complete and up  to  date  procedures  in  place  to  govern  and  guide  activities  so  that  legal  and  national requirements are met. Ensures that all patients on a cancer PTL are being managed pro-actively to avoid harm
Director of Operations:

Accountable for  planned  care  performance,  actions  taken  to  mitigate  non-performance  and ensuring that each responsible service is compliant with governance arrangements in place for their area of responsibility
Associate/Deputy Director of Nursing for Cancer:
Accountable for maintaining quality of care in cancer. Oversight of serious incidents and resulting root cause analysis
Ensuring Harm Reviews happen in line with SOP
Ensure any lessons learnt/actions are followed up and completed
Associate Directors of Operations, Service Managers & Divisional Clinical Directors:

Accountable for overseeing compliance with this SOP. Ensuring that effective processes are in place to manage patient care and treatment that meet national, local and NHS Constitution targets and standards for each specialty within the relevant division
Medical Director for Cancer / Site Medical Director:
Expected to chair the harm review panel meetings
Expected to sign off and confirm the following on the breach report:
Consultants:

Responsible for managing patient care and treatment, working with their Directors/Associate Directors, Service Managers and clinical colleagues to ensure that this is provided within timescales laid down in national, local and NHS constitution targets and standards
Responsible for completion of clinical harm review for patients breaching cancer standards within 2 weeks of receipt from governance lead.
They should attend LHRP or arrange for clinical deputy to attend on their behalf
They should decide whether the breach was avoidable or unavoidable and decide what level of harm is associated with the breach
Responsible for ensuring a clinical review of any patient under their care who is on or beyond day  of a cancer pathway
Tumour site pathway directors:
Should have site of the harm review process within their tumour site
Responsible for reporting themes from Harm reviews to MSE Cancer Committee
Responsible for ensuring themes/ learning from harm reviews is incorporated into pathway and quality improvement work in their tumour site, including discussion at Network Cancer Groups when relevant
Clinical Nurse Specialists:
Responsible for supporting patients through the cancer pathway
Responsible for clearly documenting when there has been clinical intervention or psychological support provided to patient at any point along their pathway
Cancer Services:
Co-ordinate the harm review process.
Complete Cancer RCA timeline once first treatment is complete
Report breach onto incident reporting system.
Patient Safety Team:
To support timely review by the ERG where the Harm Review Panel has identified of patient harm graded as moderate or above.
To support declaration in line with the National Serious Incident Framework.
Governance Managers/Leads:
Co-ordinate the reviews, ensuring the relevant Clinician receives the appropriate documentation within one week of receipt
Ensure that clinical review is undertaken and clinical sign off takes place for each breach
Quality check completed reviews before forwarding onto the harm panel for sign off
Return the completed Clinical Harm Review to the Harm Review Co-ordinator within one week of completion by clinician
Escalate the incident if harm is found, following trust SI process
Close incidents following confirmation of ‘no harm' following that harm panel
Clinical Service Managers:
Review  the  RCA for  each  patient  within their specialty, ensuring  it  is a  true and accurate representation of the patient journey
Share breach reports and learning outcomes with their specialty teams
Ensure trends, themes and actions are captured and presented at the clinical governance boards
Attend the Harm Review Panel as required and take any remedial actions or pathway changes for implementation
Cancer Informatics / Data Lead:
Produce monthly data on submitted breaches
Enter MDS onto central harm review spreadsheet
Harm Review Co-Ordinator:
To receive completed harm reviews from relevant divisions
Co-ordinate the LHRP, including room booking and diary requests
Document outcomes, learning, themes and actions from LHRP
Liaise with the Patient Safety team regarding incidents where harm is identified at the LHRP and requires investigation through ERG.
Feedback outcomes to the relevant division for action
Update divisions on outcomes, prompting them to close relevant incidents
Update spreadsheet with incident numbers/dates and outcomes
Key Elements of Policy / Guideline

All patients who are diagnosed with cancer and who receive their first treatment more than 62 days after an urgent cancer referral from primary care, after a ‘consultant upgrade' from secondary care or through a screening programme will be identified by the Cancer Team. A RCA process will be undertaken to understand the delays within that individual patient pathway and a Harm Review will be performed as outlined in the Cancer Harm Review Process SOP (summarised in appendix 1).

All patients who receive first cancer treatment more than  days after a decision to treat has been made will be also be identified by the Cancer Team. An RCA and a Harm Review will be performed as outlined in the Cancer Harm Review Process SOP.

Any patient whose care does not meet clinically acceptable waiting times, despite not breaching any constitutional standard, will receive an RCA and Harm Review as outlined in the Cancer Harm Review Process SOP.

Any patient who has been referred on a routine pathway but is subsequently found to have cancer will have a harm review undertaken, even if treatment has not breached a cancer constitutional standard, if they have waited more than 3 months from referral to consultant upgrade to a cancer pathway.
An  initial  assessment  for  possible  harm  will  be  based  on  any  positive  answer  to  the following questions:
Was a tumour thought to be operable now inoperable as a result of the delay?
Has a delay meant that patient has had to have more radical surgery than first anticipated?
Has a delay meant that disease progression has precluded some treatment options that would have been applicable?
Has a delay in treatment meant that a patient has loss of functionality that is greater than anticipated, commensurate with their disease?
Are you aware of/has there been any prolonged psychological harm (28 days or more)?
Additionally, the harm review will ask if the patient had undergone any investigations in the last 12 months for the same symptoms, prior to this current referral.
Assessment of possible harm is made by an expert clinical team and reviewed by a Harm Review Panel with a membership comprising of:
Site Medical Director (Chair)
Medical Director for Cancer (Deputy Chair)
Associate/Deputy Director of Nursing for Cancer
Cancer Service Manager
Consultant undertaking clinical harm review
Operational Service Manager for the relevant tumour site service
Patient Safety Manager
CCG representative
NHS Specialised Commissioning representative
Primary Care representative
Harm Review Co-ordinator

Where the possibility of harm is raised by the assessing clinician or Harm Review Panel the case is escalated as a possible SI through the incident reporting process and Patient Safety Team to the ERG for review.
An SI is reported when there is felt to have been unexpected or avoidable death, harm or injury to patient as a result of the delay to diagnosis and/or treatment
Where harm is likely to have occurred Duty of Candour is applied and is auditable
The NRLS principles are followed in relation to both physical and psychological harm (Appendix 3)
Learning and service improvement planning from the Tumour site Harm Reviews will be:
Disseminated through service clinical governance meetings
Reported to MSE Cancer Committee as part of the Tumour Pathway Director monthly reports
Discussed through Network Cancer Groups to provide support and challenge for clinical teams
Themes from the Harm Review process will be presented quarterly to MSE Cancer Committee
All patients waiting for diagnostics to diagnose or rule out cancer or waiting for cancer treatment will be reviewed at least weekly at the cancer patient tracking list meeting
Any patient who has been on a cancer pathway for 90 days or more is escalated to the clinical team for:
Clinical review to ensure that immediate action is not necessary to mitigate against potential physical harm
Contact and support from the clinical nurse specialist if not already in place to mitigate against potential psychological harm
Any patient who has been waiting for more than 104 days for diagnosis or treatment will be escalated at the PTL meeting through the hospital site Managing Directors to the Trust Chief Executive
In order to minimise long waits for diagnosis and treatment, national best practice pathways, and any adaptions recommended in special circumstances (eg pandemics) will be adopted.
Training Requirements
All staff involved in the Cancer and Harm Review pathways will have specific induction in relation to the implementation of this policy and the associated procedure.

Excessive wait but no change in symptoms from referral expected Pathway issue is administrative and patient has not come to harm or is not expected to come to harm Patient died of a condition other than referral relates to, where the treatment provided would not have offered longer life.

Any unexpected or unintended incident that required extra observation or minor treatment and caused minimal harm to one or more persons receiving NHS-funded care.

What are you proposing to change?
The process for Harm Reviews has developed significantly since the previous site based procedures. This policy supports the procedural SOP that has been recently released across the MSE.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)

We now have a more robust harm review process which provides monitoring and assurance. This policy clearly defines the guiding principles and responsibilities of the associated procedural SOP for the MSE.
Who benefits from this change and how?

It will give Divisions/Directorates reviewing the Cancer pathway the ability to develop action plans based on learning from harm reviews, thus improving patient care and experience, and reducing potential of future patient harm.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
